video.title: Build an Instagram Clone with React Native, Firebase Firestore, Redux, Expo - Full Course
video.description:
Learn how to build an Instagram clone using React Native, Firebase Firestore, Firebase storage, Redux, and Expo. The app includes an authentication system, database, storage, and more.

💻 Code: https://github.com/SimCoderYoutube/InstagramClone

✏️ Course from SimCoder. Check out their channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQ5xY26cw5Noh6poIE-VBog

⭐️ Links ⭐️
🔗 https://firebase.google.com/docs/auth/web/start
🔗 https://reactjs.org/docs/getting-started.html
🔗 https://expo.io/
🔗 Redux tutorial: https://youtu.be/CVpUuw9XSjY

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:02:28) Setting up React Native Expo
⌨️ (0:16:34) Auth System With Firebase and React Native
⌨️ (0:56:33) Save Data Using Firebase And Redux
⌨️ (1:29:05) Handling Navigation on React Native
⌨️ (1:49:43) Using Camera And Image Gallery With React Native
⌨️ (2:12:57) Saving An Image Post Using Firebase Firestore and Firebase storage
⌨️ (2:42:38) Displaying User Profile With Firebase Firestore
⌨️ (3:11:57) Search User By Similar Name with Firebase Firestore
⌨️ (3:36:00) Follow System Using Firestore And React Native
⌨️ (3:55:42) Post Feed System With Firebase and React Native
⌨️ (4:27:48) Logout Firebase Auth And Redux React Native
⌨️ (4:35:24) Adding User Comments To Posts W/ Firebase Firestore
⌨️ (5:14:00) Like System Using Firestore
⌨️ (5:47:25) Redesign Release

⭐️ Special thanks to our Champion supporters! ⭐️ 
🏆 Loc Do
🏆 Joseph C
🏆 DeezMaster

This has to be the most in-depth and real use case tutorial on YouTube!

I think we can look into pagination ourselves but if you can point to where you would implement it in your code that would be a great start! 

Any other information would also be great!

Thanks again for your help and videos! 👍

topLevelComment.author: David Vishwakarma
topLevelComment.text:
You attempted to use a firebase module that's not installed on your Android project by calling firebase.app().

Ensure you have:

1) imported the 'io.invertase.firebase.app.ReactNativeFirebaseAppPackage' module in your 'MainApplication.java' file.

2) Added the 'new ReactNativeFirebaseAppPackage()' line inside of the RN 'getPackages()' method list.

topLevelComment.author: Nadav Ossendryver
topLevelComment.text:
I got stuck with the const uid = snapshot.query.EP.path.segments[1] line that everyone else did too. 
1. Change to const uid =  snapshot.docs[0].ref.path.split('/')[1]
2. Also, then change to dispatch(fetchUsersFollowingPosts(user.uid));  ---- Not user.id
3. The biggest thing that helped me, is you must follow someone WITH posts, otherwise it still throws an "undefined" error. [Unhandled promise rejection: TypeError: undefined is not an object (evaluating 'snapshot.docs[0].ref')]

Hope it helps.

So take care of that... Happy Coding:)

topLevelComment.author: Dvir Bartov
topLevelComment.text:
SECURITY NOTE: One comment regarding exposing the firebase config object: it's ok to put it on the client side and commit it to version control, since it's not really secret. see: https://firebase.google.com/support/guides/security-checklist

Additionally, please do not use environment variables to store sensitive information on the react native client side. One can easily inspect the app bundle and retrieve your secret credentials. Instead, you can build an orchestration layer (e.g. a node server) that holds all your sensitive information. see: 
https://reactnative.dev/docs/security

topLevelComment.author: Daniel Wildegger
topLevelComment.text:
The idea of the tutorial is great and I'm sad to say it but its just not "good". There are so many moments where things just don't  work as you do them, where additional packages are needed or it seems like things work due to your setup.

I'm at "Using Camer And Image Gallery With React Native" now and it just doesn't work. Neither in the browser, nor on the phone. 

On the phone the camera is not even the problem, but firebase. "firebase.default.firestore is not a function". No clue where that comes from. Why does it work for you? No clue either, nor is the internet of much help.


I'm not a newbie in software development, I know how to use Google to solve problems, read error messages and interpret them. But here I feel like I'd invest the energy only to run into a similar situation in the next chapter.

Its sad because at this step this tutorial ends for me - there is no sense in continuing to follow along if the camera doesn't work in the browser or my Android.

EDIT after finding a way to fix firebase error and make it at least not crash:
To safe mobile: In redux/actions/index.js add "import '@firebase/firestore'" on top of the file. That will avoid the crash on Android.

In general: 
Always use try-catch around async code! Even tho simcoder does not do it, it will allow you to at least keep your application usable and display a message that lets you know where the actual problem comes from. To make it not crash in the browser I had to add a try-catch around the async function in the useEffect hook in Add.js. In the catch I was able to log an error and setHasPermissions(false); which will show at least whats going on on the screen.
